docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 COMPETENCE AND COMPELLABILITY OF WITNESSES [ss 12–20]

heading.title: DIVISION 1 COMPETENCE AND COMPELLABILITY OF WITNESSES [ss 12–20]

p.text: This Chapter is about ways in which evidence is adduced.
Part 2.1 is about adducing evidence from witnesses.
Part 2.2 is about adducing documentary evidence.
Part 2.3 is about adducing other forms of evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 COMPETENCE AND COMPELLABILITY OF WITNESSES [ss 12–20]

p.text: Except as otherwise provided by this Act:
every person is competent to give evidence, and
a person who is competent to give evidence about a fact is compellable to give that evidence.
ALRC 26 Vol 1 para 525
ALRC 38 para 64
Legislation cited in [50,130.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 13, ss 14–19.

A witness is to be presumed to be competent until the contrary is shown: R v Brooks (1998) 44 NSWLR 121; (1998) 102 A Crim R 367; BC9803148 and, as is apparent from the terms of s 13 , the requirements of competence are not demanding. If a witness is competent, the witness is also compellable. In this the Act follows the general law: Riddle v R (1911) 12 CLR 622; 18 ALR 103 ; Hoskyn v Cmr of Police [1978] 1 All ER 136; R v Hutton (1932) 49 WN (NSW) 91; (1932) 32 SR (NSW) 282 . Exceptions to this general principle of compellability are few. They are contained in ss 14–19 of the Act.
Legislation cited in [50,130.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Oaths Act 1900 ss 12–13.

It was not always the case that the requirements of competence were so undemanding. Until 1744, and the decision in Omychund v Barker (1744) 1 Atk 21; 26 ER 15, only Christians were competent witnesses since they alone could take an oath on the gospel (see now Oaths Act 1900 ss 12–13 , which confer an unconditional right to make an affirmation in lieu of an oath). A person convicted and sentenced for a crime of infamy, such as felony, treason or perjury, was incompetent as a witness for the rest of his or her life unless he or she was pardoned. Until the last decade of the nineteenth century, even accused persons were not competent to give sworn evidence in their own defence. Any person who had an interest in the proceedings, even though not a party, was not a competent witness. At common law, though not in Chancery, parties were not competent witnesses until the mid-nineteenth century. Further, the incompetence of parties extended, with certain exceptions, to their spouses and endured even after divorce: see generally Cross on Evidence, 2nd Aust ed, ch 8.
A person is not competent to give evidence about a fact if, for any reason (including a mental, intellectual or physical disability):
the person does not have the capacity to understand a question about the fact, or
the person does not have the capacity to give an answer that can be understood to a question about the fact,
and that incapacity cannot be overcome.
See sections 30 and 31 for examples of assistance that may be provided to enable witnesses to overcome disabilities.
A person who, because of subsection (1) , is not competent to give evidence about a fact may be competent to give evidence about other facts.

A person who is competent to give evidence about a fact is not competent to give sworn evidence about the fact if the person does not have the capacity to understand that, in giving evidence, he or she is under an obligation to give truthful evidence.
A person who is not competent to give sworn evidence about a fact may, subject to subsection (5) , be competent to give unsworn evidence about the fact.
A person who, because of subsection (3) , is not competent to give sworn evidence is competent to give unsworn evidence if the court has told the person:
that it is important to tell the truth, and
that he or she may be asked questions that he or she does not know, or cannot remember, the answer to, and that he or she should tell the court if this occurs, and

that he or she may be asked questions that suggest certain statements are true or untrue and that he or she should agree with the statements that he or she believes are true and should feel no pressure to agree with statements that he or she believes are untrue.
It is presumed, unless the contrary is proved, that a person is not incompetent because of this section.
Evidence that has been given by a witness does not become inadmissible merely because, before the witness finishes giving evidence, he or she dies or ceases to be competent to give evidence.

For the purpose of determining a question arising under this section, the court may inform itself as it thinks fit, including by obtaining information from a person who has relevant specialised knowledge based on the person’s training, study or experience.
[s 13 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[3], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 236–245, 521–524
ALRC 38 paras 64–65
ALRC 102 paras 4.3–4.89
Legislation cited in [50,135.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 13(3), s 13(5).

The competence of a witness will be presumed until the contrary is shown. No presumption of incompetence arises from the age of the witness: R v Brooks (1998) 44 NSWLR 121 at 124E; 102 A Crim R 367; BC9803148 . The general common law principle is that a witness must understand the nature and consequences of making an oath to be competent to give sworn evidence: R v Hill (1851) 2 Den 254; 169 ER 495; Spittle v Walton (1871) LR 11 Eq 420; R v Dunning [1975] Crim LR 372; R v Sparkman (1930) 31 SR (NSW) 80; 48 WN (NSW) 8 ; R v Brasier (1779) 1 Leach 199 1779 R v Sparrow [1973] 2 All ER 129; (1973) 57 Cr App R 352 at 358, 362 and 364 ; see also R v Bathurst (1968) 52 Cr App R 251 at 257. Under the provisions of s 13(3) a witness is competent to give sworn evidence if they understand their obligation to give truthful evidence. That general principle does not involve any precise rule about the degree of comprehension required and the scope of the factual enquiry involved in assessing a witness’ competence is essentially the same under both the present section and under the common law: R v Brooks , above.

If the court is satisfied that a child can understand a question and give a comprehensible answer, there is no discretionary power to refuse to allow the child to give unsworn evidence: SH v Regina [2012] NSWCCA 79; BC201202970 .

The conditional authorisation in s 13(5) (to admit unsworn evidence) only arises if the person is incapable of understanding the obligation to give truthful evidence: see R v Brooks , above. If a question arises as to the witnesses competence, either in relation to sworn or unsworn evidence, it is appropriate for the trial judge to undertake an equiry to determine the question: see R v Fitzsimmons (NSWCCA, 60259/97, 19 June 1998, unreported, BC9803155); R v JTB [2003] NSWCCA 295; BC200306069 . This is so irrespective of whether or not the question arises because of either intellectual or physical disability: see R v Hutton (1932) 49 WN (NSW) 91; (1932) 32 SR (NSW) 282 at 287 . Neither party bears any onus in relation to establishing that a witness is not competent. The question of competence is a matter to be determined on the balance of probabilities: see RA v R (2007) 175 A Crim R 221; [2007] NSWCCA 251; BC200708075 at [11] .

The requirements of s 13(5) must be fully satisfied. But the requirement in s 13(5)(c) is substantive, not prescriptively formal. There are two limbs to the required instruction, each involving the idea of a “suggestion” that evidence may be true or untrue. Those two limbs reflect common forms of cross examination, and it is those suggestions that must be covered by the instruction: SH v R [2012] NSWCCA 79; BC201202970 . Section 13(6) requires the court to act on the basis that the presumption is the fact, unless the contrary is proved. The “contrary” fact must be proved to the civil standard: North Sydney Leagues’ Club Ltd v Synergy Protection Agency Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 168; BC201203982 .
Legislation cited in [50,135.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 135–139.
The evidence given by a witness who dies is not inadmissible, but the exclusionary discretions conferred in ss 135–139 may apply.
A person is not compellable to give evidence on a particular matter if the court is satisfied that:

substantial cost or delay would be incurred in ensuring that the person would have the capacity to understand a question about the matter or to give an answer that can be understood to a question about the matter, and
adequate evidence on that matter has been given, or will be able to be given, from one or more other persons or sources.
[s 14 am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 1 January 2009]
None of the following is compellable to give evidence:
the Sovereign,
the Governor-General,
the Governor of a State,
the Administrator of a Territory,
a foreign sovereign or the Head of State of a foreign country.
A member of a House of an Australian Parliament is not compellable to give evidence if the member would, if compelled to give evidence, be prevented from attending:
a sitting of that House, or a joint sitting of that Parliament, or
a meeting of a committee of that House or that Parliament, being a committee of which he or she is a member.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,150] s 16 Competence and compellability: judges and jurors

leg:heading.title: Competence and compellability: judges and jurors

p.text: A person who is a judge or juror in a proceeding is not competent to give evidence in that proceeding. However, a juror is competent to give evidence in the proceeding about matters affecting conduct of the proceeding.
A person who is or was a judge in an Australian or overseas proceeding is not compellable to give evidence about that proceeding unless the court gives leave.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 247–248, 527
ALRC 38 para 68

level.toc-caption: [50,150.10] Competence and compellability of judicial officers

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,150.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 129, s 16.

heading.title: Competence and compellability of judicial officers

p.text: A distinction is drawn in s 16 between a judge in current proceedings (in which case the judge is not competent to give evidence in those proceedings) and a judge in former proceedings (in which case the judge is competent, but only compellable with leave, to give evidence about those proceedings). The first of these provisions is consistent with the position at common law, that a judge is not compellable to give evidence about proceedings in which the judge has been engaged: Hennessy v Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd (1926) 38 CLR 342 at 349; 26 SR (NSW) 67 ; Duke of Buccleuch v Metropolitan Board of Works (1872) LR 5 HL 418; Zanatta v McCleary [1976] 1 NSWLR 230; Taylor v Director, Serious Fraud Office [1999] 2 AC 177 (contents of documents not able to be disclosed and not actionable). The second provision represents some variation of the common law position by contemplating that leave may be given to compel the judge to give evidence. It is difficult to anticipate the circumstances in which leave would be given, particularly given the prohibition in s 129 of the Act against the use of evidence about the judge's deliberations or about the reasons for decisions. Neither the mere fact of the relevance of the evidence, nor the judge's competence to give evidence, will afford a sufficient basis for the grant of leave. It is likely that the favourable exercise of the discretion to grant leave will require an applicant to show special circumstances.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,155] s 17 Competence and compellability: defendants in criminal proceedings

leg:heading.title: Competence and compellability: defendants in criminal proceedings

p.text: This section applies only in a criminal proceeding.
A defendant is not competent to give evidence as a witness for the prosecution.
An associated defendant is not compellable to give evidence for or against a defendant in a criminal proceeding, unless the associated defendant is being tried separately from the defendant.

If a witness is an associated defendant who is being tried jointly with the defendant in the proceeding, the court is to satisfy itself (if there is a jury, in the jury’s absence) that the witness is aware of the effect of subsection (3) .
Associated defendant is defined in the Dictionary .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,160] s 18 Compellability of spouses and others in criminal proceedings generally

leg:heading.title: Compellability of spouses and others in criminal proceedings generally

p.text: This section applies only in a criminal proceeding.
A person who, when required to give evidence, is the spouse, de facto partner, parent or child of a defendant may object to being required:
to give evidence, or
to give evidence of a communication between the person and the defendant,
as a witness for the prosecution.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[5], effective 1 January 2009]
The objection is to be made before the person gives the evidence or as soon as practicable after the person becomes aware of the right so to object, whichever is the later.

If it appears to the court that a person may have a right to make an objection under this section, the court is to satisfy itself that the person is aware of the effect of this section as it may apply to the person.
If there is a jury, the court is to hear and determine any objection under this section in the absence of the jury.
A person who makes an objection under this section to giving evidence or giving evidence of a communication must not be required to give the evidence if the court finds that:

there is a likelihood that harm would or might be caused (whether directly or indirectly) to the person, or to the relationship between the person and the defendant, if the person gives the evidence, and
the nature and extent of that harm outweighs the desirability of having the evidence given.
Without limiting the matters that may be taken into account by the court for the purposes of subsection (6) , it must take into account the following:
the nature and gravity of the offence for which the defendant is being prosecuted,
the substance and importance of any evidence that the person might give and the weight that is likely to be attached to it,
whether any other evidence concerning the matters to which the evidence of the person would relate is reasonably available to the prosecutor,
the nature of the relationship between the defendant and the person,
whether, in giving the evidence, the person would have to disclose matter that was received by the person in confidence from the defendant.
If an objection under this section has been determined, the prosecutor may not comment on:
the objection, or
the decision of the court in relation to the objection, or
the failure of the person to give evidence.
ALRC 38 paras 79–83
ALRC 102 paras 4.90–4.116
Legislation cited in [50,160.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Dictionary, child, criminal proceeding, defacto partner, parent.
These terms are defined in the Dictionary : child, parent and criminal proceeding, defacto partner.

level.toc-caption: [50,160.15] Compellability of spouses and other family members

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,160.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 18(6), s 19.

heading.title: Compellability of spouses and other family members

p.text: The section assumes the compellability of an accused person’s spouse, parent or child. The assumed spousal compellability provided for in the section is not to be read down by the application of common law presumptions: see R v Glasby (2000) 115 A Crim R 465; [2000] NSWCCA 83; BC200003417 at [53]–[55] . However, the word "spouse" is not defined in the Act. Consequently it is unclear whether a divorcee could assert the right to object: see Monroe v Twistleton (1802) Peake Add Cas 219; 170 ER 250 ; R v Algar [1954] 1 QB 279; [1953] 2 All ER 1381 ; Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions v Smiles (1993) 30 NSWLR 248 .

The section confers on this limited range of family members a right to object to giving evidence as a prosecution witness in any criminal proceedings — other than the child protection offences excluded in s 19 of the Act. Where the right to object is available, the court must satisfy itself that the person is aware of the right to object.

If the objection is taken, and the court is satisfied that the harm likely to be caused by the person giving evidence would outweigh the desirability of having the evidence given , the person cannot be required to give evidence.

In performing the comparison required by the s 18(6) test for the purposes of determining an objection, the court must take account of the policy reasons which underlie the section. These include the fact that potential exists for harm to be caused to a domestic relationship if spouses are required to give evidence in proceedings brought against their partners, even if no particular harm can be readily identified: R v Flentjar (No 2) [2008] NSWSC 648; BC200805093 .

level.toc-caption: [50,160.20] Competence and compellability of spouses — historical

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,160.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 ss 407–407AA.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 11.
(CTH) Family Law Act 1975 s 100.

heading.title: Competence and compellability of spouses — historical

p.text: At common law spouses were, with certain exceptions, not competent witnesses whether their evidence was sought to be adduced for or against the other: Bentley v Cooke (1784) 3 Dougl 422; 99 ER 729. By the middle of the nineteenth century, spouses became both competent and compellable in civil proceedings: Phipson on Evidence, 14th ed, para 9-06. By the end of the nineteenth century legislative provisions made spouses competent, but not compellable, witnesses in criminal proceedings: eg, ss 407–407AA of the Crimes Act 1900; Leach v R [1912] AC 305 . At about the same time there was also statutory creation of a privilege against the disclosure of marital communications: s 11 of the Evidence Act 1898. No such privilege existed at common law: Rumping v DPP [1964] AC 814 ; and it was excluded in family law proceedings by the s 100 of the Family Law Act 1975. The present Act establishes that, in relation to civil proceedings, spouses are in the same position as any other potential witnesses. In relation to criminal proceedings, spouses are competent and compellable subject to their ability to make an effective objection under the present section.
Legislation cited in [50,160.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 20.
The absence of evidence from a family member may be the subject of comment in accordance with s 20 of the Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,165] s 19 Compellability of spouses and others in certain criminal proceedings

leg:heading.title: Compellability of spouses and others in certain criminal proceedings

p.text: Section 18 does not apply in proceedings for an offence against or referred to in the following provisions:

section 25 (Child abuse), 26 (Neglect of children), 51 (Endangering children in employment) or 52 (Certain employers of children to be authorised) of the section 222 (Endangering children in employment), 223 (Certain employers of children to be authorised), 227 (Child and young person abuse) or 228 (Neglect of children and young persons) of the Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998
section 279 (Compellability of spouses to give evidence in certain proceedings) of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986.
This section differs from section 19 of the Commonwealth Act.
[s 19 am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003 ; Act 158 of 1998 Sch 2.14, effective 9 December 2011]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,170] s 20 Comment on failure to give evidence

leg:heading.title: Comment on failure to give evidence

p.text: This section applies only in a criminal proceeding for an indictable offence.

The judge or any party (other than the prosecutor) may comment on a failure of the defendant to give evidence. However, unless the comment is made by another defendant in the proceeding, the comment must not suggest that the defendant failed to give evidence because the defendant was, or believed that he or she was, guilty of the offence concerned.
The judge or any party (other than the prosecutor) may comment on a failure to give evidence by a person who, at the time of the failure, was:
the defendant’s spouse or de facto partner, or
a parent or child of the defendant.
[subs (3) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[6], effective 1 January 2009]

However, unless the comment is made by another defendant in the proceeding, a comment of a kind referred to in subsection (3) must not suggest that the spouse, de facto partner, parent or child failed to give evidence because:
the defendant was guilty of the offence concerned, or
the spouse, de facto partner, parent or child believed that the defendant was guilty of the offence concerned.
[subs (4) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[7], effective 1 January 2009]
If:
2 or more persons are being tried together for an indictable offence, and
comment is made by any of those persons on the failure of any of those persons or of the spouse or de facto partner, or a parent or child, of any of those persons to give evidence,
the judge may, in addition to commenting on the failure to give evidence, comment on any comment of a kind referred to in paragraph (b).
[subs (5) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[7], effective 1 January 2009]
Legislation cited in [50,170.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Dictionary, “child”, “criminal proceedings”, “defacto partner”, “parent”.
These terms are defined in the Dictionary : “child” , “parent” and “criminal proceedings” , “defacto partner” .

The word “comment” is not defined in the dictionary. However, it should be interpreted as any statement that directly or indirectly suggests that evidence could have been given but was not: DJF v R [2011] NSWCCA 6; BC201100851 ; see also R v Villar; R v Zugecic [2004] NSWCCA 302; BC200405865 .

level.toc-caption: [50,170.10] Comment on failure to give evidence

heading.title: Comment on failure to give evidence

p.text: This section permits judicial comment on the failure of an accused person (or a family member) to give evidence. It prevents comment that suggests “absence from the witness box is to be equated with guilt”: R v Sparrow [1973] 2 All ER 129; (1973) 57 Cr App R 352 at 358, 362 and 364 ; see also R v Bathurst (1968) 52 Cr App R 251 at 257. The section empowers a trial judge – but not the Crown Prosecutor – to comment upon the failure of an accused person to give evidence, subject to the qualification that the comment must not suggest that the accused failed to give evidence because they believed they were guilty of the offence alleged: see R v Yammine (2002) 132 A Crim R 44; [2002] NSWCCA 289; BC200204077 .

The provisions of the section deal only with the situation where an accused person chooses to remain silent. It has no bearing on those situations (to the extent that they still exist) where an accused person charged prior to the commencement of the Crimes Legislation (Unsworn Evidence) Amendment Act and who retains the right to make an unsworn statement chooses to exercise that right. The nature of any comment which might be made in that case must be determined according to common law rules which are left unaffected by the provisions of the Evidence Act 1995: see R v Milat (NSWSC, Hunt CJ, 70114/1994, 23 April 1996, unreported, BC9607720).
If a defendant does not give evidence it will almost always be desirable for the trial judge to warn the jury that the accused’s silence:
is not evidence against them
does not constitute an admission
may not be used to fill gaps in the prosecution evidence and

may not be used as a make weight in assessing whether the prosecution evidence has been proved beyond reasonable doubt: Azzopardi v R (2001) 205 CLR 50 at 70; 179 ALR 349; [2001] HCA 25; BC200102009 .

However, a warning will be sufficient if it clearly conveys that the accused’s failure to give evidence cannot be used as evidence against them. Provided the direction does not convey the contrary impression, it is not necessary for the trial judge to explicitly warn the jury against using the accused’s silence in evaluating the strength of the prosecution evidence: R v Wilson (2005) 62 NSWLR 346; [2005] NSWCCA 20; BC200500719 at [57] per Grove J .

A comment or direction under the present section is not permissible if it suggests that the jury can draw inferences adverse to the accused from the fact of their failure to give evidence (see RPS v R (2000) 199 CLR 620; 168 ALR 729; BC200000084 ) that the absence of evidence from the accused is relevant in assessing the strength of the prosecution case: Azzopardi v R (2001) 205 CLR 50; 179 ALR 349; [2001] HCA 25; BC200102009 ; c/f Weissensteiner v R (1993) 178 CLR 217; 117 ALR 545; BC9303617 . R v Giri (2001) 121 A Crim R 568; [2001] NSWCCA 197; [2001] NSWCCA 197; BC200103011 . Similarly, it is impermissible to comment that accused persons may not want to give evidence because of a belief that if they did so, their evidence might “fill in gaps” in the Crown case: R v Sullivan [2002] NSWCCA 505; BC200208032 .
